lessonOverview.title: Unit 1 - Lesson 1
structures: A: What’s your favourite sea animal?
B: My favourite sea animal is the dolphin.
A: What’s his/her favourite sea animal?
B: His/Her favourite sea animal is the shark.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six sea animals (dolphin, shark, seahorse, seal, octopus, crab) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Use SB images or flashcards. Call out a sea animal, students race to point or label it. Then ask: “What colour is it?” to extend.
stretchStrategies: Students create a short “Sea Animal Interview Show,” asking and answering about favourites, then present 1 fact or reason about their chosen animal.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about sea animals using “What’s your favourite sea animal?” / “What’s his/her favourite sea animal?” and respond with “My favourite sea animal is the...” / “His/Her favourite sea animal is the...”.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Create a class survey: students ask 3 peers “What’s your favourite sea animal?” and report to the class.
stretchStrategies: Students create a short “Sea Animal Interview Show,” asking and answering about favourites, then present 1 fact or reason about their chosen animal.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “What’s your favourite sea animal?” / “What’s his/her favourite sea animal?” / “My favourite sea animal is the ___.” / “His/Her favourite sea animal is the ___.” to talk about preferences.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Display sentence frames: “My favourite sea animal is…” / “His favourite is…” Students practise by guessing their partner’s favourite.
stretchStrategies: Students create a short “Sea Animal Interview Show,” asking and answering about favourites, then present 1 fact or reason about their chosen animal.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)
A wide variety of syllabus hobbies may be less popular or available to some Vietnamese students (practising the flute; seeing famous paintings), although many overlap
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Certain common holiday activities are less likely to overlap with those of Western kids (eating seafood at the beach, going on tours in large groups)
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
